title: Fifty Years Ago
excerpt: Looking back at bridge events and articles from 50 years ago.

Then, if North ruffed with the king of hearts and returned a trump, the eight of hearts would be the necessary entry to the ace of spades, declarer's tenth trick. Eventually, Zia did play a diamond and we thought he would make the contract, but he went wrong and ruffed low. Now, he could not successfully follow the line of play described above, because North could ruff high and kill dummy with a trump return. Instead, Zia ruffed a club and led the last diamond. Had Perron made the mistake of ruffing low, Zia could have overruffed, led a spade to dummy, and scored his last trump en passant. However, Perron correctly discarded his last spade on the diamond, and Zia was down one. A fascinating deal. The U. S. was lucky to split the board. In the Closed Room, the French judged badly and arrived at three spades, which was set one trick.

**Fifty Years Ago**

Many of the top players of fifty years ago had a great flair for card play. Often, they seemed to conjure up a brilliant line of play or defense with little or no calculation, as though through intuition or inspiration. No one exemplified the instinctive player more, in quality or quantity of superior plays, than Harry Fishbein. This Fishbein exploit, from the team-of-four event at the 1947 Winter Nationals, was reported in the Jaunary, 1948, issue of The Bridge World.
A popular start to the auction was:

Four hearts was a popular contract around the room. The defense attacked spades, and most Souths discarded diamonds on the second and third rounds of the suit, keeping control—except that hearts broke five-one so the contract was defeated.

Fishbein was the only South to make four hearts. He ruffed the second spade, cashed two clubs, and crossruffed for ten tricks. Notice that discarding at tricks two and three relies on better than five-one breaks in two suits, hearts and clubs, while the winning line requires only one decent break, in clubs. Still, we doubt that Fishy calculated the exact odds.

JOHN LOWENTHAL: "Double. If I sell out to one spade, partner will have,

♠ x x ♥ J x x x x x ♦ x ♣ x x x x.

If I reopen, he will have,

♠ x x ♥ x x x ♦ x x x ♣ K J x x x.

I choose double rather than one notrump so that partner will evaluate heart length correctly (not to mention that one notrump doesn't look like a very appetizing contract)."

But one notrump looked quite palatable to:

PAUL TRENT: "One notrump. Best bid not to miss game. Partner has to act if interested."

But his action would be three notrump if he held,

♠ x x ♥ x x x ♦ x x ♣ A Q J x x x.

ERIC RODWELL: "One notrump. Not pass with 18 points and shape. Partner can investigate hearts if he has enough to bid. This is more descriptive (and safer) than double followed by two notrump over two clubs."

RON GERARD: "One notrump. Even if North passes one notrump with,

♠ x x ♥ Q x x x x ♦ J x x ♣ x x x,

it's only a part-score swing. If he takes out to two clubs, he should have more play than if he bids two clubs in response to a double."

KIT WOOLSEY: "One notrump. Doesn't this show a balanced hand too strong for an opening notrump bid? Exactly what I have. (Well, almost exactly.)"

MARSHALL MILES: "One notrump. I think game is very unlikely, but the opponents might make one spade."

Quite a thorough job by the panel. The arguments for all the actions make

sense, and we suspect that this is one of those problems with no theoretically right (or wrong) answer.

EDDIE KANTAR: "One notrump. Must mix it up a bit with such a good hand."

Eddie, no need to send one of those letters of complaint. 100 points for you and 360 out of 500 so far.

**Problem F**

Matchpts.; none vul. You, South, hold:

(F1) Do you agree with South's pass? (y|n)
(F2) Is North's sequence consistent with 3=3=2=5 distribution? (y|n) (F3) What call do you make?

F1 is fairly straightforward. The people who vote "No" (they want to make a negative double) will be happy if partner names a major after their double, distraught if he bids three notrump or passes.

HENRY BETHE: "F1. Yes. I suspect the popular vote will be for a negative double, but how will partner guess to bid a three-card major rather than to try three notrump or to pass?"
